name: Pilot
description:
A very new hops introduced in 2002 by Charles Faram and Co Ltd.  Mild herbal flavor with lemon hints and fresh mowed grass flavor.  
Used for: Primarily for bittering in APAs.Rare.

name: Apolon
description: A Slovenian hybrid that is a cross between Brewer's Gold and a Yugoslavian wild male.  Once thought to be related to Super Styrian.  Traditionally bred for bittering can also be used as an aroma hop.

name: Aquila
description:
Aroma hops developed in 1988.  Limited use due to high cohumolone.
Used for: Aroma hopsSubstitutes: Cluster
No longer commercially grown.

name: Greensburg
description: American hop variety from southern Idaho.  Fruity flavor with a touch of wood flavor.  Popular with microbreweries.

name: Pilgrim
description:
New variety from Wye College in 2001.  High Selinene content.
Used for: BitteringSubstitutes: N/A

name: African Queen 2018
description:
African Queen is a South African bred high alpha, daylight neutral hop whose pedigree is a diploid seedling selected from a cross between 91J7/25 and an SA male 94US2/118.  The aroma profile includes dank, blueberries, stone fruit, black currant, gooseberries, bubble gum, lemongrass, and chilies.  Total oil content is around 1.3 percent, alpha acids range from 12 to 17 percent, and cohumulone is low at about 26 percent.  Works well with all hop-forward beers, including American and Belgian styles.  Also works well with subtle blended beers such as those with coffee, fruit, and spices.  Possible similar hops: Mosaic, Simcoe, Citra.

Experimental SAB hop. J17/63 is a day neutral high alpha variety, which requires moderate planting distances and an average of 9-10000 strings and 27-30000 bines per hectare.  Bines are vigorous and perform well on a standard framework. The medium sized cones with an average volume of 0.24g are semi tight, dense and pick very easily.  The cone to leaf ratio is 60:40.  Alpha development is normal.Because of the excellent alpha acids content and good yields, J17/63 gives a very high alpha acid production per hectare.

Cohumulone 26.5%, Storeability (Pellets) TBC, Isomerisation (Pellets) TBC, Total Oil ml/100g 1.3%, Humulene 21.4%, Caryophyllene 12.8%, Hum/Car Ratio 1.7, Farnesene 4.9, Myrcene 28.4%

name: Challenger
description:
Variant of Northern Brewers heritage
Used for: Both aroma and bittering for ales and lagersAroma: Fruity in flavor, spicy aroma, blends well
Substitutes: N/A

name: Jarrylo
description:
Notes: Underwhelming hop. Good if used in combination of hops with stronger flavors like Amarillo.

Aroma: Banana, pear, spice.

name: Bouclier
description: A cross between Alsace grown Strisselspalt and a wild male plant from Wye, Kent.  Grassy with hints of spice.  Aromas of herbs, grass, spice with some floral and citrus character.

name: Summit
description:
High alpha variety bred by American Dwarf Hop Assoc.  Can be grown commercially on a low trellis.  
Aroma: Strong citrus, grapefruit notes.Substitutes: Warrior, Millenium, Columbus, Tomahawk, Zeus

name: Cryo - Cascade
description: A classic Pacific NW Hops - floral, citrusy, prized in IPAs.  Lupulin powder - typically used during the whirlpool/steep or dry hop phases at about half the volume of pellet hops to mazimize aroma/flavor.  Concentrated to enhance hop oils. Store near freezing.

name: Centennial Hop Hash
description:
Technically this is lupulin powder similar to Cryo-hops.  It is intended for use primarily in the whirlpool, hot steep or for dry hopping.

Columbus, Tomahawk and Zeus are collectively called CTZ and are similar in character and often blended.  They provide citrus aromas, black peper, licorace and curry notes.

name: Aurora
description:
Also called Super Styrian.  This is a hybrid between Northern Brewer and TG.  It has a pleasant hoppy aroma similar to Styrian Goldings but lighter.  
Used for: Often mixed with other hops in lagers.Substitutes: Styrian Goldings

name: HBC 342 (Experimental)
description:
As this is an experimental variety, there is no guarantee this hop will come to market en masse. Data obtained from HopUnion. "High alpha variety with a pleasant aroma"
Uses: Pale AleAroma: Mild citrus, tropical fruit and melon notes 
Substitutions: Unknown (Belma or Citra?)Storage: Unknown
??% AA / ??% Beta

name: Azacca
description:
Notes: Dual purpose hop. Good for dry hopping
Aroma: Citrus, tropical, floral

name: Pacific Hallertau (aka Pacifica)
description:
Hallertau variant which produces a typical Mittelfruh aroma combined with smooth bouquet and mild buttery flavor notes; typical of the flavor achieved in classic European lagers
Used for: Australian Ales, European lagerAroma: Clean, floral with slight cinnamon-like spiciness. Orange marmalade and citrus aroma notes when used in late addition.  Soft finish if used in bittering.
Substitutes: Chinook, Hallertauer Mittelfruh, Liberty, Mt. HoodStorage: Good/Very Good
5-6% AA / 5.5-6.2% Beta

name: Green Bullet
description:
Bittering hops from New Zealand developed in 1972
Used for: Australian-style ales and lagers.Aroma: Floral, raisin aroma.
Substitutes: Styrian Goldings

name: Tettnang (Tettnang Tettnager)
description:
One of the four noble hops along with Saaz, Spalt, and Hallertau Mittelfrueh, a group of mainland European hops that are prized for their similar, delicate flavor and aroma profile.
Used for: German ales, lagers, wheatAroma: Noble, Mild and pleasant with balanced earthy, herbal and floral aroma impressions
Substitutes: Saaz, Spalt, Hallertau MittelfruehStorage: Poor
2.5-6% AA / 3-5% Beta

name: Glacier
description:
Genetic mix of at least 8 hops including Elsasser, Brewers Gold, N Brewer, Bullion, Early Green, and others...released in 2000.
Used for: AromaAroma: Excellent, hoppy
Substitutes: N/A

name: Herald
description:
Dwarf variety bred at Wye College (mid 1990s)
Used for: Bittering of alesAroma: Strong, acceptable
Substitutes: High alpha English bittering hops

name: Marynka
description:
Bittering hops with high aroma.  Primarily for use in Pilsner, lagers, ales or wheats.  Comparable to English Goldings or Chinook.  
Used for:Lager, ales
Substitutes: Chinook, English Golding

name: Olympic
description:
Olympic is a high alpha hops released by Washington Agricultural Expt Station in 1983.  Heritage is from Brewers Gold and Fuggles.
Aroma: Spicy, citrus aromaSubstitutes: Brewers Gold

name: Sun
description:
A very high alpha bittering hops from Yakima Valley, Washington
Used for: Bittering (intense)Aroma: Pleasant, hoppy
Substitutes: Other very high alpha US hops

name: Hallertauer Mittelfrueh
description:
Used for: Continental Lagers, German Ales/Lagers, US Lagers
Aroma: Pleasant, assertive, mild herbal aromaSubstitutes: Hallertauer, Mt. Hood, Liberty, Crystal
Examples: Sam Adams Boston Lager, Sam Adams Boston Lightship

name: Kirin II
description: A Japenese hop that grew from Japan's decision to reduce hop imports.  Grown domestically in Japan under government contract.  Developed by Kirin Brewery, it is a direct descendant of Saaz and White Vine.

name: Comet
description:
Very bitter hops - use sparingly with other hops
Used for: Bittering onlySubstitutes: N/A

name: Junga
description: A high alpha bittering hop from Poland similar in some ways to German Magnum but with a nuce aroma.  Derived from a Saaz variety.  Substitute: Nugget, German Magnum or Target

name: N1/69 2018
description:
Experimental SAB hop
SAB fact sheet: "Oranges, Plums, %Coh 26.4"zahops.com: "The aroma profile of N1/69 is Kool-Aid, Juicy Fruit, mango, citrus, plums, dank, and pungent.  Alpha acids are 13.4 percent and cohumulone is 23 percent in 2016."
northernbrewer.com: "pineapple, citrus, and melon flavors, along with some Juicy Fruit and Kool-Aid notes. Try it in your next IPA or APA. Typical Alpha Acids 13%. Aroma hop. Perfect for tropical IPAs. Typical Alpha Acids 13%. "

name: Tahoma
description: Citrus and lemon notes with cedar, pine, floral, pepper and subtle green melon notes. Daughter of Glacier that retains the very low cohumulone characteristic of Glacier with somewhat higher alpha acid content.

name: Golding, U.S.
description:
Mild and delicate with sweet floral characteristics. Bred in the US from east Kent Golding. Golding hops consist of a group of traditional English aroma varieties which have been cultivated since 1790. Severalselections now exist including Cobbs, Early Bird, East Well, Bramling, Canterbury and Mathon, some of which are now being grown in the U. S. All Goldings are recognized as having a most typical English aroma.

Used for: BitterSubstitutions: Fuggle, Willamette, UK East Kent Golding, Styrian Golding

name: El Dorado Hop Hash
description:
Technically this is lupulin powder similar to Cryo-hops.  It is intended for use primarily in the whirlpool, hot steep or for dry hopping.

El Dorado brings forward some tropical fruit flavors of pear, watermelon and stone fruit.

name: Eroica
description:
Used for: General purpose bittering for ales, porters, stouts
Aroma: Clean bittering hop, very bitterSubstitutes: Galena, Northern Brewer, Chinook
Examples: Blackhook Porter, Ballard Bitter

name: Teamaker
description: Developed by the USDA, Teamaker was released in the late 2000's.  It is a unique high beta, very low alpha breed sued in medicine and food industries as well as brewing.  It has very strong antibiotic properrties, and makes a tasty iced tea.  It imparts almost no bittering content, but has floral aromas.  Use as a late addition either whirlpool or dry hopping.

name: Zlatan
description: A Czech hop released in 1976 and derived from Saaz.  Created in Zatac by the Hop Research Institute it attempts to maintain the character and aroma of Saaz.  It has a more mild bitterness and noble aroma if used late, as a whirlpool or dry hop addition.

name: Agnus
description:
Several large Czech breweries like Agnus as a bittering hop because its alpha/beta ratio is relatively high, which they believe makes their beer more stable. High geraniol level, oils indicate dry hopping potential.
Used for: AlesAroma: Strong hop aroma, spicy
Substitutions: UnknownStorage: Unknown
9-15% AA / 4-8% Beta

name: Tomahawk
description:
Part of the Columbus/Tomahak/Zeus (CTZ) group of super high alpha hops.  Together these make up 1/4 of US hop acreage.  
Used for: High alpha hops used primarily for commercial bittering.Substitutes: Tomahawk, Zeus, Nugget, Galena, Chinook

name: Mandarina Bavaria
description:
One of four new varieties released to German growers in 2012. Shares characteristics of its mother, Cascade, but fruitier and more herbal.
Used for: American pale ale, lager (as late hop)Aroma: Distinct tangerine and citrus flavors
Substitutions: UnknownStorage: Unknown
7-10% AA / 4-7% Beta

name: Northern Brewer
description:
Also called Hallertauer Northern Brewers
Used for: Bittering and finishing both ales and lagers of all kindsAroma: Fine, dry, clean bittering hop.  Unique flavor.
Substitutes: Hallertauer Mittelfrueh, HallertauerExamples: Anchor Steam, Old Peculiar,

name: Mosaic (HBC 369)
description:
Available in quantity for the first time after 2012 harvest. Still known to many as HBC 369. A daughter of Simcoe crossed with a Nugget derived male. An excellent aroma variety.
Used for: Ales, IPA, Experimental AlesAroma: Rich in mango, lemon, citrus, pine, and notably, blueberry.
Substitutes: UnknownStorage: Good (25% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
11-13.5% AA / 3.2-3.9% Beta

name: Pekko
description:
Notes: Any style that coud incorporate Saaz could use Pekko.

Aroma: Floral, mint, herbal, citrus

name: Cryo - Simcoe
description: An earthly, citrus, pine hop widely used in IPAs and many American styles.  Lupulin powder - typically used during the whirlpool/steep or dry hop phases at about half the volume of pellet hops to mazimize aroma/flavor.  Concentrated to enhance hop oils. Store near freezing.

name: Flyer
description: A cross between a high alpha female breeding line and low trellis male. Released for trials in 2009.  A citrus hop with aromas of stoned fruit, liquorice, tracle-toffee and caramel with slight burnt notes.  Spicy, resinous, citrus and liquorice notes.

name: Hallertau Blanc
description:
Floral and fruity with passion fruit, grapefruit, pineapple, grape and lemongrass overtones. One of several new German varieties with bold flavor profiles, perfect for American-style Ales.

Used for: American style ale
Substitutions: N/AStorage Unknown

name: Nugget
description:
Used for: Bittering hops for ales
Aroma: Strong bittering, heavy, herbal aroma, spicySubstitutes: Chinook
Examples: Sierra Nevada Porter

name: Viking
description: Developed in 1968 at Wye College in England.  A cross between Svalof and an English male plant.  High alpha for a British hop - the aroma is described as pleasant and hoppy.

name: Southern Dawn
description: A relatively new South African hop used by some large breweries.  Resembles Southern Promise but with a different aroma profile.  Has a fruity, spicy aroma and is relatively neutral when bittering.

name: Amallia
description: A native plant from New Mexico and part of the neomexicana varietal.  Trialed by Michigan State University in 2014. A deeply earthy aroma with flavors of orange citrus. Well suited for brown or dark ales.

name: Chinook
description:
Strong versatile bittering hop
Used for: Ales, porters, stoutsAroma: Heavy and spicy aroma
Substitutes: Galena, Eroica, Nugget, BullionExamples: Sierra Nevada Stout, Sierra Nevada Celebration Ale

name: Columbus (Tomahawk)
description:
Engineered Centennial Substitute - High alpha bittering hops.
Used for: Bittering, flavor, aroma - IPA, American Pale Ale, Stout, LagerAroma: Pungent, spicy. Strongly aromatic, but clean tasting bitterness
Substitutes: Centennial

name: Fuggle, Organic
description:
As Fuggle (U.K.), only organic variety
Typical alpha: 3-5%. Organically grown Fuggle hops from the UK. Wonderful earthy, pipe-tobacco, floral character. Classic hop for any English ale.

name: Hallertauer, New Zealand
description:
Hallertauer variant with classic aroma and ability to retain clean taste. Bred from German Hallertauer Mittelfrueh
Used for: Australian AlesSubstitutes: Hallertauer Mittelfrueh

name: Herkules
description:
A German high alpha cross variety, bred in Huell and released in 2005. Imparts robust, hoppy tang flavors.
Used for: hoppy German-style ales or lagersAroma: Spicy floral and hop notes, with hints of pine, lemon and black pepper.
Substitutions: UnknownStorage: Good
13-17% AA / 4-5.5% Beta

name: Galena
description:
Used for: General bittering hops for all beers
Aroma: Strong, clean, balanced bitteringSubstitutes: Eroica, Northern Brewer, Cluster, Chinook
Examples: Catamount Porter

name: Lublin
description:
Version of Saaz grown in Poland - also called "Lubelski"
Used for: Bohemian lagers and PilsnersAroma: Noble, mild flavor similar to Saaz
Substitutes: Saaz, Tettnanger

name: SAB PIH Blend
description: Blend Pre-isomerised hops. 12-14% (70% S.Star, 25% S.Prom. 5% other).

name: Satus
description:
High alpha bittering hops from Yakima that is similar to Galena.  Of recent origin.  
Substitutes: Galena

name: Ella
description: Ella was formerly known as Stella.  Its an Australian variety that is a half sister to Galaxy and related to Spalt.  It was released in 2007 for trials and became quite popular.  Ella has a very high aromatic oil content that changes depending on how its used.  In small quantities it provides a spicy, floral quality like star anise.  Larger quantities or dry hopping provide more of a tropical or grapefruit flavor.

name: Cryo - Palisade
description: A earthy, floral, fruity hop used for aroma including apricot, grass and floral components. Lupulin powder - typically used during the whirlpool/steep or dry hop phases at about half the volume of pellet hops to mazimize aroma/flavor.  Concentrated to enhance hop oils. Store near freezing.

name: Super Alpha
description:
High alpha hops released in 1976 by DSIR. European in character - clean crisp flavor and resin aroma.
Used for: European Styles, General purpose bitteringAroma: Pleasant, resin like aroma
Substitutes: N/A

name: Goldings, B.C.
description:
Used for: Bittering and finishing British ales, bitters, porters and stouts.
Aroma: Spicy, floral, rounded mild aroma.Substitutes: East Kent Goldings, Fuggles

name: Progress
description:
Used for: Bittering and aroma in English Ales
Aroma: Similar to Fuggles, aromatic, slightly sweetSubstitutes: Fuggles

name: Southern Passion 2014
description:
Fruity, passion fruit and slightly spicy.

Formerly known as US4/78. This locally bred aroma type hop variety was selected specifically for South African conditions.  It is a very vigorous variety requiring wide planting distances.  The medium size cones are slightly spiky, neat and tight with an average cone volume of 0.16g.  The cone to leaf ratio is 80:20.Cohumulone 16.6-20.2%, Total Oil ml/100g 0.8-1.0%, Humulene 17-26%, Caryophyllene 10-13%, Hum/Car Ratio 2.7 - 3.4%, Farnesene 0.1-0.4%, Myrcene 20-35%

name: Southern Star
description: Southern Star

name: Southern Passion 2018
description:
Southern Passion is a South African bred aroma daylight neutral hop whose pedigree is a diploid seedling originating from Saaz and Hallertauer crossing.  The aroma profile includes passion fruit (granadilla), guava, red berries, melon, calendula, and grapefruit - very unique.  Total oil content is about 1 percent, alpha acids range from 8 to 12 percent, and cohumulone is very low from 16 to 20 percent.  Noble hop pedigree represented in alpha and beta acids being about equal.  Works well with a variety of beer styles including lightly hopped session beers, and all hop-forward beers of American and Belgian origins such as pale ales, IPAs and Saisons.  Possible similar hops: none.

Formerly known as US4/78. This locally bred aroma type hop variety was selected specifically for South African conditions.  It is a very vigorous variety requiring wide planting distances.  The medium size cones are slightly spiky, neat and tight with an average cone volume of 0.16g. name: 92P24 2015
description:
Experimental SAB hop.
No data."Bittering hop with and alpha of Â±14.5%"

description: A Russian aroma hop that is actually a parent of Cascade. Not widely grown in the US, but still available in some areas.  Hints of black tea, herbs, tobacco with high humulene and fanesene content that contributes to pleasant continental aroma and taste.

name: Belma
description:
New variety produced at Puterbaugh Farms. First introduced to public Fall 2012.
Used for: Expedrimental Ales and LagersAroma: A very clean hop, with a very orange, slight grapefruit, tropical (but not mango/guava, more like pineapple), strawberry, and melon
Substitutions: UnknownStorage: Unknown
9.8% AA / ??% Beta (5 year avg not yet established)

name: Bitter Gold
description:
Intense stone fruit especially pear and watermellon. A super-alpha variety with excellent aroma.

Used for: All StylesSubstitutions: Galena, Nugget

name: Ahtanum
description:
Distinctive aromatic hops with moderate bittering power from Washington.
Used for: American ales and lagersAroma: Distinctive floral and citrus aromas
Substitutes: Amarillo, Cascade

name: Cascade, New Zealand
description:
Flowers, citrus and spice with grapefruit the noticeable fragrance quite often. This medium aroma balances the low bittering value. Very popular hop among craft brewers.

Used for: Pale Ales, IPAs, PortersSubstitutions: Centennial, Amarillo

name: SAB T90 Blend 2011
description: Unknown blend??

name: SAB T90 Blend 2010
description: Unknown blend??

name: Feux-Coeur
description: Australian hop with genetic roots back to Burgundy France.  Fairly rare breed from Victoria.

name: Defender
description: Bred from a New Mexico wild female and Eastwell Golding male at Wye College, England.  Low alpha and yield has limited acreage.  A pleasant European style aroma.

name: Delta
description:
A backcross between Fuggles and Cascade, recently released (2012) by the Hopsteiner breeding program. Woody and herbal with a citrus kick. Not as assertive as dual purpose hops but adds distinctive notes in a blend.
Used for: IPA, Pale AleAroma: Mild and pleasant aroma; slightly spicy with a hint of citrus.
Substitutions: Fuggle, WillametteStorage: Excellent (80-90% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
5-7% AA / 5-7% Beta

name: Pioneer
description:
Bred from Wye Omega at Wye College in the UK
Used for: ESB, English AlesAroma: Mild English hop aroma
Substitutes: East Kent Goldings

name: El Dorado Hop Extract
description:
CO2 Hop Extract -sold in both 0.5kg (150 gma), 1 kg (300 gma), 2 kg, 3kg and 4kg cans.  Extracted from El Dorado hops and only for use in the boil.  Measure out liquid in ml for use.

Check alpha percentage listed here against the can as alpha may vary by season and manufacturer.

name: Goldings, US
description: UK Golding clones have been introduced for growing here in Washington and Oregon. Before being grown in the US, there was a Golding grown in British Columbia (BC Golding), there are no longer any more BC Golding hops grown.

name: Liberty, New Zealand
description: Mild and spicy, subtle lemon and citrus. Used in many styles. Contributes good bitterness in the beginning of the boil and an aroma of grapes, peaches, and vanilla at the end of the boil. Derived from Hallertau Mittlefruh.

name: Palisade
description:
Also called YCR-4, Palisade is an aroma variety bread by Yakima Chief Ranches.  It has both aromatic and moderate bittering properties.  
Substitutes: Willamette

name: Golding, New Zealand
description:
Mild, delicate sweet floral character

Used for: English AlesSubstitutions: NZ Willamette, NZ Styrian Golding, NZ Fuggle, UK East Kent Golding

name: Denali (Exp 06277)
description: Formerly hopsteiner experimental #06227.  Denali is a high alpha aroma hop with heritage to Zeus and Nugget as well as a USDA male.  It has a big aroma including pineapple, citrus and pine notes.  High essential oil content makes it suitable for dry hopping or whirlpool additions such as IPAs.

name: Fuggle, New Zealand
description:
Fuggle is the classic English aroma hop and is often used in conjunction with Goldings. It can be used as a main boiling hop to impart a mild, soft grassy/woody floral aroma and is also used for dry hopping.

Used for: English Ales, Porter, Stout, English IPASubstitutions: UK Fuggle, NZ Willamette, NZ Styrian Golding

name: Legacy
description: Legacy has been cultivated in Washington state for over 50 years, but was registered and named in 2013.  It has some wild notes of blackberry, black currant, orange, grapefruit and florap and spicy notes.

name: Moutere
description:
Formerly called 'Brooklyn'.  A high alpha hop with distinctive tropical, grapefruit and passion fruit characters. Developed from Southern Cross.

Used for: IPAsSubstitutions: N/A

name: Amethyst
description: Low alpha aroma hops related to saaz grown in the Czech Republic. Citrusy, earthly and spicy.  Substitutes: Saaz

name: Chinook Hop Extract
description:
CO2 Hop Extract -sold in both 0.5kg (150 gma), 1 kg (300 gma), 2 kg, 3kg and 4kg cans.  Extracted from Centennial hops and only for use in the boil.  Measure out liquid in ml for use.

Check alpha percentage listed here against the can as alpha may vary by season and manufacturer.

name: Tardif de Bourgogne
description: "Late Burgundy" hops grown in small quantities in Alsace, France.  A mild European style aroma. Very limited quantities commercially.

name: Calicross
description: New Zealand Calicross was developed in the 1960's and largely disappeared in the 1980s.  Can still occasionally be found.  A cross between Fuggle and Late Cluster.  Earthy, fruity flavors with floral aromas.  Substitute: Cluster

name: Nelson Sauvin
description:
Triploid variety bred from "Smoothcone" released in 2000.  Oil profile said to taste like "fresh crushed gooseberries" similar to Sauvignon Blanc, giving it its name.  Very fruity, citrusy - use in moderation.  
Used for: Pale ale, Super Premiums.Substitutes: None

name: Motueka
description:
Flexible hop developed from Saaz.  Has notable character and aroma, balanced bitterness, and unique flavor.  
Used for: Lagers, Belgian Ales and Bohemian Pilsner.Substitutes: Saaz

name: HBC 438
description: An experimental hop that is a cross between a neomexicanus and YCR 123.  It is sister to HBC 472 and has similar character.  Aromas include mango, coconut, grapefruit, lemon grass and wood.  Peachy stone fruit, pineapple., lime and herbal notes of cedar and coconut.  A disctinct hop.  Subsitute: HBC 472

name: Select Spalt
description:
Bred from Hallertauer Mittelfrueh and Spalt in Germany.  Spalt character.
Used for: Lager, Pilsner, Noble aroma hop substituteAroma: Very fine, spalt aroma
Substitutes: Spalter, Saaz, Tettnang

name: Melba
description: Called the "Dame of Hops", Melba is a dual purpose hop from Australia's Ellerslie Hop Estate.  It has a high oil content and moderate alpha acid making it suitable for late and dry hop additions.  Adds a spicy bitterness. Aromatics of passion fruit, grapefruit, and citrus.  Comparable to Galaxy.

name: Gold
description: Daughter of Styrian Savinsjki Golding released in 2009.  Distinct aroma grown only in Slovenia.  Aroma of honey, oregano, basil, nettle and hay.

name: Jester
description: Developed by Charles Faram and Co, a proprietary hop different than most UK hops.  Aromatic notes of tropical fruit, grapefruit, blackcurrent and Lychee.  A late addition or dry hop, but not recommended for bittering in the boil.  Closer to a New World hop style.

name: Orbit
description: Selected from a NZ hop breeding program, available in limited quantities.  Resinous, piney, aromatic and some notes of tropical fruit.  Some variation from year to year due to varieties selected.

name: Aurora (Super Styrian Aurora)
description:
Also called Super Styrian Aurora.  This is a hybrid between Northern Brewer and TG.  Pleasant hoppy aroma similar to Styrian Golding but lighter.
Used for: Strong Ale, Pale Ale, BitterAroma: Intense and pleasant hoppy aroma
Substitutes: Styrian GoldingStorage: Excellent/Very Good (80-85% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
7-9% AA/ 3-5% Beta

name: Fuggle, U.S.
description:
This classic English aroma variety has long been grown in both Oregon and Washington. It has a typical English aroma and contributes a balanced bitterness. Fuggle is very suitable for English and American-style Ales. Mild wood and fruit characteristics.

Used for: English AlesSubstitutions: Willamette, UK Fuggle, Styrian Golding

name: Columbia
description:
Sibling of Williamette hops.
Used for: All English AlesAroma: Close to Fuggles
Substitutes: Fuggles, Williamette

name: Pacific Sunrise
description: A bittering hop released by Hort Research in 2000.  limited production.  A pleasant piney aroma.  Cross between a California Late Cluster, Fuggle and New Zealand male plant.

name: Super Galena
description:
Super high alpha hops from Hopsteiner breeding program released in 2006.  High alpha and beta content - comparable to Galena in bitterness and aroma profile.  
Used for: Primarily for bitterness.Substitutes: Galena

name: Merkur (Hallertauer Merkur)
description:
Sometimes called Hallertauer Merkur, this variety was bred from a cross between Hallertaur Magnum and variety 81/8/13 from the Hull Hops Research Institute.  Mostly used for bittering qualities, appropriate for early to mid additions.
Aroma: Strong earthy, floral and citrus impressionsSubstitutions: Maganum (U.S.), Hallertau Magnum
Storage: Fair/Good (60%-70% AA after 6 months at 20 C)12-16.2% AA / 5.1% Beta

name: Canadian Redvine
description: From Canada and very disease resistant.  It has a very high cohumulone content and low alpha making it a good late hop candidate.  Aroma and flavor of berries, pine, cherry and grapefruit peel.

name: Citra
description:
Special aroma hops released in 2007.  Imparts high alpha/oil content but low cohumulone.
Aroma: Adds interesting citrus and tropical fruit character to the beer.Substitutes: Unknown

name: Cryo - Citra
description: Lupulin powder - typically used during the whirlpool/steep or dry hop phases at about half the volume of pellet hops to mazimize aroma/flavor.  Concentrated to enhance hop oils. Store near freezing.

name: Wakatu (Hallertau Aroma)
description:
Formerly called Hallertau Aroma. Similar to German Hallertau but higher alpha. Excellent Dual Purpose hop, rounded floral aroma with hints of lime. 
Used for: Lager, Pils, Bock, Wheat, Kolsch, Helles, Belgian Ales.Aroma: Restrained floral notes and freshly zested lime
Substitutions: US Hallertau, LibertyStorage: Good
6.5-8.5% AA / 8-9% Beta

name: Hallertauer
description:
Used for: German Ales, German/US/Canadian Lagers, Wheat Beers
Aroma: Pleasant, mild spicy flavor, clean, neutral flavorSubstitutes: Crystal, Liberty, Hallertauer Mittelfrueh

name: Crystal
description:
Used for: Aroma and finishing hops for Lagers
Aroma: Clean, mild, pleasant and slightly spicySubstitutes: Hallertauer, Mount Liberty

name: HopShot
description:
CO2-extracted hop resin that can be used for bittering or late additions to boiling wort.  Primarily for use in boil.  Made from Columbus (or CTZ) blend hops.
http://www.northernbrewer.com/documentation/hopshot.pdf

name: Feux Coeur Francais
description: Rare, high alpha hops from Australia with genetic roots in the Burgundy region of France.  It was adopted to the Victoria region of Australia and introduced in 2010.

name: Huell Melon
description:
Distinct fruit characteristics including honeydew melon and strawberry flavors. An excellent consideration for varieties not necessarily associated with typical hop flavors.

Substitutions: N/AStorage Unkonwn

name: Sybilla
description: A varity from Poland which is primarily for bittering but has some good aromatic properties.  A mix of Lublin and Slovenian Styrian Goldings.  Good aroma hop with soft contintental character similar to a German Hallertauer, English Fuggles or Sterling.

name: Archer
description: A new variety from the Charles Faram Hop program.  Classic British aroma with a citrus twist.  Aroma is floral with delicate hints of lime and peach.  Provides traditional British assertiveness.

name: Relax
description: From Barth-Haas group - originally bred for tea and not beer.  Only 0.25% alpha acid and a huge beta acid punch and high oil content.  Use in whirlpool or dry hop for aroma oils.  Aromas of alpine meadows, lemongrass, hibiscus, cornflower and honeydew melons.

name: Sterling
description:
Flavor is a cross between Saaz and Mt Hood
Used for: Lagers, Ales, PilsnersAroma: Herbal, spicy, some floral and citrus hints
Substitutes: Saaz, Polish Lublin

name: Tradition
description:
Close descendant of Hallertauer Mittelfrueh bred for high yield.
Used for: Lager, Pilsner, Bock, some WeizensAroma: Fine - similar to Hallertauer Mittelfrueh
Substitutes: Hallertauer Mittelfrueh, Liberty, Ultra

name: Brooklyn
description:
A high alpha hop with distinctive tropical, grapefruit and passion fruit characters. Developed from Southern Cross.

Used for: IPAsSubstitutions: N/A

name: Cashmere
description:
Daughter of Cascade. Mild herbal aroma with strong melon, lemon, and slightly spicy notes.

Used for: American Pale Ale, IPASubstitutions: N/A

name: Falconer's Flight 7C's Blend
description:
A proprietary hop blend from HopUnion that includes 7 of the "C" hops along with a few experimental varieties.
Used for: Pale Ale, IPA, Experimental AlesAroma: Citrus/grapefruit character alongside fruity, spicy, and earthy notes
Substitutions: UnknownStorage: Unknown
9-10% AA / 4.5% Beta

name: Liberty
description:
Used for: German style lagers
Aroma: Fine, mild, slightly spicy flavorSubstitutes: Hallertau, Mt Hood, Crystal
Examples: Pete's Wicked Lager

name: Cekin
description: Developed at the Hop Research Inst in Slovnia in the 1980's.  A cross between Aurora and a Yugoslav male.  Not grown in large quantities.  Pleasing and continental aroma similar to Savinjski Golding.  Substitute: Savinjski Golding or Aurora

name: Amarillo
description:
Discovered and introduced by Vigil Gamache Farms Inc. in Washington State. Character similar to Cascade.  Often used as a late kettle or dry hop addition to American style Pale Ales and IPAâs due to its signature aroma characteristics. Used for both bitterness and aroma.
Used for: IPAs, AlesAroma: Intensely fruity (citrus, melon, and stone friuts), floral, tropical notes.
Substitutes: Cascade, Centennial, SimcoeStorage: Good
8-11% AA / 6-7% Beta

name: U3/108 2018
description: Experimental SAB hop

name: Bullion
description:
Used in strong dark English ales, some heavy German lagers.
Aroma: Strong, pungent and bitter in flavor.  Blackcurrant flavor.Substitutes: Chinook, Eroica, Brewer's Gold

name: Styrian Golding (Savinja Golding)
description:
A seedless version of Fuggle grown in Slovenia. Popular in Europe and the United Kingdom.
Used for: All Ales and LagersAroma: Delicate, slightly spicy, soft, and floral aroma. Similar to Fuggle.
Substitutes: Fuggle, Williamette, EKGStorage: Very Good
4.5-6% AA / 2-3.5% Beta

name: Southern Promise 2009
description:
South African bred, low chill, day neutral variety; a diploid
seedling from a cross between Southern Brewer and a wildYugoslavian male.

name: Gesho Kitel
description: Brundo's aroma hops Gesho stems, gathered from the highlands of Ethiopia, are sun-dried and packed fresh. These aromatic sticks and stem flavor centuries old traditional brewing recipes for beer and Ethiopian honey wine. Acid content unknown.

name: Phoenix
description:
Seedling derived from Wye Yoeman.
Used for: AlesAroma: Similar to Wye Challenger hops
Substitutes: Challenger, East Kent Golding, Northdown

name: Northdown
description:
Variation of Northern Brewers hops grown in England.
Used for: Bittering in English alesAroma: Good bittering, flavor and aroma
Substitutes: Northern Brewer

name: Spalter Select
description:
Bred from Hallertauer Mittelfrueh and Spalt in Germany.  Solid replacement for Sazzer-type hops.
Used for: Lager, PilsnerAroma: Spicy, floral, and woody.
Substitutes: Spalt Spalter, Saaz, TettnangerStorage: Good/Fair
3-6.5% AA / 2.5-5% Beta

name: Sussex
description:
Aroma similar to Fuggle. Good, yet delicate, flavor retention. Pedigree is "a chance find". 

Used for: AleSustitution: N/A
Storage: Unknown

name: Cascade
description:
A hops with Northern Brewers Heritage
Used for: American ales and lagersAroma: Strong spicy, floral, grapefruit character
Substitutes: CentennialExamples: Sierra Nevada Pale Ale, Anchor Liberty Ale

name: Beata Hops
description: Beata is a low alpha British aromatic hop developed at Wye College in the UK in 1995 though it did not go into production until 2006.  Lovely aroma, with classic British complexity.  High beta levels also contribute unique properties.  Honey, apricot and almond notes.

name: Mathon White
description:
A very old varitety which may have been bred from Farnham Whitebine or Caturbury Whitebine like Goldings was.  A pleasant aroma similar to Goldings.  Goes well in most any English style.
Substitute: Kent Goldings or Bramling

name: Columbus/Tomahawk/Zeus (CTZ)
description:
Engineered Centennial Substitute - High alpha bittering hops.
Used for: IPA, American Pale Ale, Stout, Lager, Barley WineAroma: Pungent, spicy. Strongly aromatic, but clean tasting bitterness
Substitutes: Other CTZ, Galena, Chinook, Nugget, Target (U.K.), Northern Brewer (Germany)Storage: Poor/Very Poor (45-65% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
14-16.5% AA / 4-5% Beta

name: Whitbread Golding Variety (WGV)
description:
Derived in England in 1911 from Bates Brewer. Some Golding characteristics, but lacking the full Goldings aroma.
Used for: AlesAroma: Pleasant, hoppy, slightly intense
Substitutes: East Kent Goldings, Progress

name: Cluster
description:
Used for: General purpose bittering hop
Aroma: Floral, slightly spicy. Sharp aroma and sharp flavor
Substitutes: Eroica, Galena

name: Monroe
description: A new hop variety from Barth-Haas group.  Only 2.5% apha but a fairly high oil content.  Mild and smooth, full of red aromas including raspberry notes and orange syrup.

name: Willamette, New Zealand
description:
Mild, pleasant, slight spicy floral tones.

Used for: American and English AlesSubstitutions: US Willamette, Fuggles

name: Hallertauer Hersbrucker
description:
Used for: German style lagers and wheat beers
Aroma: Noble, pleasant, clean flavorSubstitutes: Mt. Hood, Liberty, Hallertauer, Mittelfrueh
Examples: Wheathook Wheaten Ale

name: Southern Promise 2010
description:
South African bred, low chill, day neutral variety; a diploid
seedling from a cross between Southern Brewer and a wildYugoslavian male.

name: Centennial
description:
Used for: General purpose bittering, aroma in American ales and Wheats
Aroma: Floral, citrus aroma, spicy, clean bittering flavorSubstitutes: Galena, Eroica, Nugget, Bullion
Examples: Sierra Nevada Celebration Ale, Sierra Nevada Bigfoot

name: Pacific Jade
description:
High alpha bittering hops that delivers a bold herbal infusion of fresh citrus with some black pepper flavor.  Citrus aroma and flavor tempers ales and may be used as a finishing hops. 
Used for: Ales, lagersSubstitutes: N/A

name: Southern Brewer
description: Developed in the early 1970's to grow in South Africa after Golden Cluster was devistated by black root.  Primarily a bittering hop, not known for its aroma or unusual flavors.  Did not grow as well in limited sunlight but was bread to create Southern Promise.

name: HBC 366 (Experimental)
description:
As this is an experimental variety, there is no guarantee this hop will come to market en masse. Data obtained from HopUnion. "The fantastic aroma combined with the high high oils make this hop very unique"
Uses: Experimental AleAroma: Exceptional aroma profile includes notes of citrus, tropical and pine 
Substitutions: UnknownStorage: Unknown
14.4-15.6% AA / 4.6-5.1% Beta

name: Southern Promise
description: A high alpha hop bred in South Africa.  Created from Southern Brewer and a wild Slovenian male hop, it was bred to grow in limited sunlight.  Has a high alpha acid and cohumulone content giving it bright, smooth bittering qualities.  Can be dual-use with woody and earthy qualities.

name: Spalter
description:
Used for: Traditional German bittering and aroma hops, Altbiers, Lagers
Aroma: Mild, pleasant, slight spiceSubstitutes: Saaz, Tettnang
Examples: Dusseldorf Altbiers

name: Sonnet Golding
description:
Sonnet is a new hop variety bred from a Saaz variant that exhibited Goldings-like characteristics. It's used for aroma due to its low alpha acid content, and offers lots of floral notes.

Used for: English Ales, Belgian Style AlesSubstitutions: Saaz,East Kent Golding and Crystal.
Storage: Unknown

name: Kohatu
description:
Moderate aroma with lime and pineapple with traces of pine. Overuse can exhibit "dank" character.

Used for: Belgian Ales, Wheat Beer, Blonde AleSubstitutions: N/A

name: Yakima Gold
description: A Washington State developed hop released in 2013.  It has mild bittering and aroma properties and is a good dual-use hop.  It decends from Early Cluster and a wild Slovenian male, so it has some Saaz like properties.  Aromas include smooth hop flavor with a hint of lemon zest and grapefruit.  Substitute: Saaz, Cluster, Cascade

name: Sticklebract
description:
High alpha hops from DSIR research first released in 1972.  Some of the same qualities as Northern Brewer
Used for: Dual purposeAroma: Pine-like with a hint of citrus
Substitutes: Northern Brewer

name: Pride of Ringwood
description:
Used for: General purpose bittering hops for Australian beers
Aroma: Moderate citric aroma, clean bittering flavorSubstitutes: Cluster, Galena

name: Topaz
description: Very high alpha hop variety from Australia.  Used for commercial production primarily for its high alpha acid content and high bitterness.

name: Simcoe
description:
High alpha bittering hops with good aroma characteristics.
Used for: IPAsAroma: Citrus and pine-like aroma
Substitutes: N/A

name: Saaz
description:
Used for: Pilsners and Bohemian style lagers
Aroma: Delicate, mild, clean, somewhat floral -- Noble hopsSubstitutes: Tettnanger, Lublin
Examples: Pulsner Urquell

name: Vital
description: A high alpha hop from the Zatac breeding program.  High alpha and beta content provide a spicy aroma.  Used in some single hop pale ales with success.

name: Harmonie
description:
With typical Czech aroma, Harmonie's finely balanced bitterness "persists" slightly longer than Saaz. Bohemie, released in 2010, is a similar Czech hop with traditional aroma.
5-8% AA / 5-8% Beta

name: Brewer's Gold, Germany
description:
Black currant, fruit and spice characteristics. Has a high resin content and gives a well-balanced bitterness which is ideally complimented by late hop additions in lager beers.

Usage: Ale, BiÃ¨re de Garde, Lambic, Lager, SaisonSubstitutions: Galena, Northdown, Northern Brewer
Storage: Unknown

name: Zeus
description:
Super high alpha bittering hops developed in the Yakima Valley, WA
Used for: Bittering, intense aromaAroma: Aromatic, pleasant
Substitutes: Other high alpha hops

name: Mt. Hood
description:
Used for: European Lagers, finishing
Aroma: Mild with a clean aroma, neutral flavor. Somewhat pungent.Substitutes: Hallertauer, Liberty, Crystal

name: Gargoyle
description: Gargoyle along with Ivanhoe are the first generation of California Cluster hops to be grown commercially in over 50 years.  Revived by Hops-Mesiter near Clearlake CA.  Similar to Ivanhoe but has a more citrus-mango bouquet.  Substitute: Ivanhoe

name: Mt. Rainier
description:
Complex parentage, including Hallertau, Galena, and Fuggle. HopUnion has stated this hop was only bred thru 2010.
Used for: LagerAroma: Excellent floral and noble aromas, with citrus and licorice tones.
Substitutions: Hallertau, FuggleStorage: Unknown
5-8.1% AA / 5-7% Beta

name: El Dorado
description:
Bred by CLS Farms, LLC, available on a larger scale for the first time during 2012 harvest. Fits the dual purpose/special mold.
Used for: Experimental AlesAroma: Tropical fruit flavors, intense aromas of stone fruits (pear, cherries), candy (Lifesavers), watermelon.
Substitutions: None at this timeStorage: Good
14-16% AA / 7-8% Beta

name: Smaragd (Emerald)
description:
Perviously known as Emerald. A fine aroma variety with high bittering value.
Used for: Alt, Kolsch, or blond ale.Aroma: Fine aroma, floral, fruity, spicy
Substitutions: UnknownStorage: Fair
4-6% AA / 3.5-5.5% Beta

name: Styrian Celeja
description:
Hybrid cross between Styrian Golding, Styrian Aurora, and Slovenian wild hops. Aroma is orange marmalade like Styrian Golding, but with a noble component.
Used for: UK and Belgian ales or lagers.Aroma: Floral, fruit
Substitutions: Unknown (Styrian Golding?)Storage: Unknown 
3-6% AA / ??% Beta

name: Sylva
description:
Formerly Southern Saaz. Displays what's considered the traditional hoppy (with cedarwood notes) and spicy character of Saaz. Mostly an option for Southern Hemisphere brewers but an interesting variation on Saaz.
Used for: LagersAroma: Complex and subtle, floral and herbal characteristics
Substitutions: Hallertau MittlefrÃ¼h, AU HelgaStorage: Unknown
4-7.3% AA / 3-5% Beta

name: Triskel
description: Triskel was developed in France in 2006.  It is a cross from Strisselspalt and Yoeman from England.  It is often used in Belgian ales and featured as a late, whirlpool or dry hop.  It has floral and citrus notes with a fruity finish.  Comes from Alsace.

name: HBC 291 (Experimental)
description:
As this is an experimental variety, there is no guarantee this hop will come to market en masse. Data obtained from HopUnion
Uses: UnknownAroma: Typically described as peppery, floral and fruity
Substitutions: UnknownStorage: Unknown
11.2-13.1% AA / 5.1-6.1% Beta

name: Styrian Bobek
description:
Derived from a Northern Brewer and Yugoslavian male TG. Low to moderate alpha and earthy, slightly fruity aroma.
Uses: English Style Ales, ESB, Lager, Pilsner and Belgian-style AlesAroma: Intense and pleasant hoppy aroma
Substitutions: Styrian Golding, UK or US Fuggle, WillametteStorage: Good
3.5-7% AA / 4-6.1% Beta

name: Cryo - Mosaic
description: Mosaic is an earthy, floral, fruity hops widely used for finishing IPAs.  Lupulin powder - typically used during the whirlpool/steep or dry hop phases at about half the volume of pellet hops to mazimize aroma/flavor.  Concentrated to enhance hop oils. Store near freezing.

name: Perle, U.S.
description:
Bred from English Northern Brewer. Slightly spicy with herbal and floral characteristics.

Used for: StoutSubstitutions: Northern Brewer, German Northern Brewer, German Perle

name: Willamette
description:
Used for: Finishing American and British Ales
Aroma: Mild, grassy, floral, slightly spicySubstitutes: Fuggles, East Kent Goldings
Examples: Sierra Nevada Porter, Ballard Bitter

name: Chelan
description:
High alpha variety from the Haas breeding program released in 2004.  It is a variant of Galena and very similar in profile to Galena.
Aroma: Pleasant citrus notesSubstitutes: Galena

name: Victoria
description:
Hi alpha hops grown in Victoria, Australia.  It was created in 1976 and entered commercial production in the 1990s.
Used for: Primarily for bittering due to high alpha content.

name: Atlas (Styrian Atlas)
description:
A cross between Brewers Gold and Slovenian wild hops.  Primarily a bittering hop with pleasant bitterness and aroma.  
Used for: Bittering ales, lagersAroma: Fresh hoppy aroma
Substitutes: Brewers GoldStorage: Very Good
7-11% AA / 3.2-41% Beta

name: Endeavour
description: Bred at Wye Hops in the UK as a cross between Cascade and a hedgerow hop.  A wonderful, citrusy hedgerow hop with complex blackcurrant, loganberry and spicy notes as well as grapefruit and lime flavor.  Gentler than cascade.  Substitutes: Cascade

name: Chinook, New Zealand
description:
Piney with exotic spice and infused with grapefruit. This alluring aroma and a high bittering value has gained this hop full respect from craft and major brewers.

Used for: American Pale Ale, IPA, Porter, StoutSubstitutions: Southern Cross, Sticklebract, Nugget, Northern Brewer

name: Eukanot
description: Released in 2014 - has strong aroma character and a very high aromatic oil content. Aroma profile includes citrus, tropical fruit, fruity and herbal components.  Flavors include melon, berry, orange peel, lime, papaya, pine and fresh pepper components.

name: Idaho #7 Hop Hash
description:
Technically this is lupulin powder similar to Cryo-hops.  It is intended for use primarily in the whirlpool, hot steep or for dry hopping.

Idaho #7 has a black tea charcter and fresh herbal aroma.

name: Bobek
description:
Also called Styrian Golding B - a cross between Northern Brewer and a TG seedling.  Pleasant hop aroma and flavor.  
Used for: Moderate English ales and lagers/PilsnersSubstitutes: Northern Brewer

name: XJA2/436 2013
description: Experimental high-alpha SAB hop. No data available.

name: Styrian Aurora (Super Styrian)
description:
Typical alpha: 7.0-9.0%. Moderate-alpha with powerful hoppy aroma, very versatile - try in US, Belgian, or English ales.
Uses: All Ales, some lagersAroma: Spicy, yet pleasant hoppiness
Substitutes: Styrian Golding, Styrian BobekStorage: Excellent
6.5-9.5% AA / 2.7-5.5% Beta

name: Dana
description: Also known as "Extra Styrian Dana" this is a Slovenian hop breed crossing a wild Slovenian male plant with German Magnum.  It has smooth bittering properties and a slightly citrus and floral aroma profile.

name: Wai-iti
description:
Strong citrus character of lime zest with fresh peaches and apricot. Used in both ales and lagers. Good for late additions and dry hopping.

Used for: Ale, Pale Ale, IPA.Substitutions: N/A

name: Cascade Hop Extract
description:
CO2 Hop Extract -sold in both 0.5kg (150 gma), 1 kg (300 gma), 2 kg, 3kg and 4kg cans.  Made from Cascade hops and only for use in the boil.  Measure out liquid in ml for use.

Check alpha percentage listed here against the can as alpha may vary by season and manufacturer.

name: Triple Pearl
description:
Pleasant and balanced with notes of melon, orange citrus, resin, spice and pepper. Stoarge stability unknown. Released in 2013 by USDA-ARS.

Used for: Pale AleSubstitutions: Perle

name: Tsingtao Flower
description:
Accounts for about 65% of acreage in China, the Chinese version of American Cluster. 
Used for: Unknown (Lager?)Aroma: Floral and SpicySubstitutions: Unknown
Storage: Good6-8% AA / 3-4.2% Beta

name: Bramling Cross
description:
Developed in 1927 from commercial Goldings and wild hop variety.
Used for: ESB, Bitters, Pale AleAroma: Mild, fruity, currant aroma.
Substitutes: East Kent Goldings, Progress, Whitbred

name: Tillicum
description:
High alpha and high beta hops developed though Haas breeding program and released in 1995.  Daughter variety of Galena and related to Chelan - so similar to both. 
Substitutes: Galena, Chelan

name: Fantasia
description: A Barth-Haas Group product said to have a flavor/profile of cream and caramel.

name: Newport
description:
High alpha hops released in 2002 as a potential replacement for Galena.  Note that these hops have a large alpha range of 9.8%-17% so check the package!  Fairly pungent.
Used for: Primarily used for bittering in ales, stouts, barley wine.Substitutes: Galena

name: Zythos
description:
A proprietary pellet blend. Designed to complement existing IPA and Pale Ale hop varieties.
Used for: American-style AleAroma: Distinct tropical (pineapple) and citrus tones, with slight pine characteristics
Substitutions: UnknownStorage: Unknown
10-12.5% AA / 4.7-6.2% Beta

name: Premiant
description:
A cross between Czech aroma and bittering varieties.  Dual purpose though its aroma is not as strong as some other Czech hops.  Use in beers where a moderate hoppy aroma is needed.  
Used for: Moderate ales, lagersSubstitutes: Saaz

name: Ivanhoe
description: A revival of the old California Cluster variety.  It has a European aroma that is more moderate than Cascade and has citrus, piney and heady floral and herbal notes.  Substitute: Cascade or Cluster

name: Santiam
description:
Triploid aroma selection derived from Tettnang and Hallertauer (1997)
Used for: Lager, U.S. Pale Ale, PilsnerSubstitutes: German Tettnang, Spalt, Spalt Select

name: Target
description:
Used for: English ales and lagers
Aroma: Robust aroma and flavorSubstitutes: East Kent Goldings

name: Tettnang, U.S.
description:
Tettnang is a traditional German land-race variety known for
its noble aroma that is pleasant and slightly spicy. It remains well established in the Tettnang growing region of Germany, and is also grown in Oregon and Washington. Americangrown Tettnang is reported to have slightly higher myrcene levels than its German counterpart.Used for: American style ale
Substitutions: German Tettnang, Santiam, German Spalt, Spalt Select

name: Waimea
description:
A high alpha acid, dual purpose hop with lots of pine and citrus characters. 

Used for: IPASubstitutions: N/A

name: Amarillo Gold
description:
Unknown origin, but character similar to Cascade.  Used for both bitterness and aroma.
Used for: IPAs, AlesAroma: Citrus, flowery
Substitutes: Cascade, Centennial

name: U1/132 2018
description:
Experimental SAB hop
brewmart.co.za: "A South African experimental hop with aroma descriptors that include guava , citrus and tropical fruit. TYPE: Bittering and Aroma"

name: Warrior
description:
High alpha hops from Yakima Chief Ranches. Also called YCR-5.  Mild aroma and low cohumulone content - primarily for bittering.
Used for: Ales, stoutsAroma: Neutral, clean, mild
Substitutes: Nugget, Columbus, Magnum

name: Banner
description:
Bittering hops developed in 1988.  Use largely discontinued due to poor storage.
Used for: U.S. style alesSubstitutes: Cluster

name: Ella (aka Stella)
description:
New name after a 2013 harvest in Australia (due to name infringement). Despite high alpha, sold as an aroma variety. When used in dry hopping or higher quantities, grapefruit and tropical characters come to the fore. Character obtained at lower rates can be best appreciated in lagers or pilsners, while the grapefruit and tropical flavors can be used to offset robust malt and yeast characters
Used for: Ales, Lagers, PilsnersAroma: tropical, subtle hints of star anise, sweet and floral, with lemon, grapefruit, apricot, and melon. 
Substitutions: GalaxyStorage: Unknown
13.3-16.3% AA / 4-7.8% Beta

name: Ultra
description:
Triploid seedling of the German Hallertauer Variety
Used for: Lager, Pilsner, wheat, finishing hops in alesAroma: Good to outstanding - some Saaz like qualities
Substitutes: Liberty, Hallertauer, Tradition, Saaz

name: Helga (Southern Hallertau)
description:
Perviously known as Southern Hallertau. Bears almost no aroma similarities to it's European cousin. Very unique aroma with moderate bittering.
Used for: Austrialian and English-style ales.Aroma: Ddelicate floral and subtle herbal aroma
Substitutes: Unknown (possible Nobel Hop variety)Storage: Unknown
5-6% AA / 3.8-5.4% Beta

name: Pacific Gem
description:
High alpha smoothcone cross developed at DSIR in 1987.
Used for: Bittering - produces a cask-oak woody flavor.Aroma: Pleasant - some blackberry aroma.
Substitutes: Bullion

name: Sovereign
description:
Pleasant but intense fruity flavors with mild floral, grassy, herbal and mint characteristics.

Used for: Pale AleSubstitution: Fuggles
Storage: Unknown

name: Medusa
description: A native hop of Colorado and New Mexico that is literally an entirely different species - humulus lupulus neomexicanus from most hops.  Strong flavor and aroma character of guava, melon, apricot, and citrus fruit.  Excellent in IPAs as whirlpool or dry hop addition.

name: Falconer's Flight
description:
Proprietary pellet blend comprised of many of the Northwest's most unique hop varieties and is perfect for any Northwest-style IPA.
Used for: IPA, Pale Ale, Experimental AleAroma: distinct tropical, citrus, floral, lemon and grapefruit tones.
Substitutions: Unknown (Citra, Simcoe, Sorachi Ace blend?)Storage: Unknown
10-12% AA / 4.4% Beta

name: Aramis
description:
Very fine spice and herbal notes with subtle citrus characteristics. Closely resembling Strisselspalt, but with higher oil and alpha content.

Used for: Belgian-style AlesSubstitutions: Willamette, Challenger, Ahtanum
Storage: Unknown

name: Outeniqua
description: A high alpha bittering hop from South Africa.  Primarily a local hop, it features a well balanced oil profile and hoppy, punchy aroma.  Mother of the high alpha variety Southern Star.

name: Brewer's Gold
description:
Traditional bittering hops for English ales and heavy German lagers.
Aroma: Sharp bittering hopSubstitutes: Northern Brewer, Galena, Chinook, Eroica
Example: Pete's Wicked Ale

name: Hallertau Taurus
description:
Bred at the Huell Hops Institute in Germany and prided in its bittering qualities. The bittering is moderately abundant and this variety adds a pleasant aroma as well.
Used for: Schwawrz, Oktoberfest, LagerAroma: seasoned, flavorful, zesty character
Substitutions: Hallertau Magnum, German TraditionStorage: Fair/Good (60%-70% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
12.3-17.9% AA / 4-6% Beta

name: Rubin
description:
The Czechs classify this as a bittering hop, but with its Saaz background it is genetically similar to European aroma varieties. Bitterness is not as smooth as Saaz, and it lingers longer.
Used for: Ales, LagersAroma: Similar to old middle European aroma hops.
Substitutions: Saaz (CZ)Storage: Unknown
9-14% AA / 3-6% Beta

name: Super Pride
description:
A high alpha variation of the Pride of Ringwood hop variety.  Features mild aromas, higher alpha content and low cohumulone levels.  
Used for: Primarily for bittering.Substitutes: Pride of Ringwood

name: Galaxy
description:
A high alpha, dual purpose seedless hops with a unique hop aroma.  It can be used either for bittering or as a late hop addition to provide a flavor of citrus and passionfruit to the finished beer.
Aroma: Intense, pleasant, unique.

name: Eureka!
description:
Notes: Offspring of Apollo and Merkur. Similar to Simcoe. Dual purpose. Good for dry hoping.

Aroma: Herbal, pine, mint, grapefruit rind, tangerine

name: Goldings, East Kent
description:
Used for: General purpose hops for bittering/finishing all British Ales
Aroma: Floral, aromatic, earthy, slightly sweet spicy flavorSubstitutes: Fuggles, BC Goldings
Examples: Bass Pale Ale, Fullers ESB, Samual Smith's Pale Ale

name: Greenburg
description: American hop variety from southern Idaho.  Fruity flavor with a touch of wood flavor.  Popular with microbreweries.

name: Southern Cross
description:
Dual purpose with "European" flavor - from DSIR in 1994
Used for: European flavor bittering/aromaAroma: Spicy, lemony, slight pine and wood flavors
Substitutes: N/A

name: Bobek (Styrian Golding B)
description:
Also called Styrian Golding B - a cross between Northern Brewer and a TG seedling.
Used for: English Ales, ESB, Lagers, PilsnersAroma: Intense and pleasant hoppy aroma
Substitutes: Northern Brewer,  Styrian Golding, UK or US Fuggle, WillametteStorage: Unknown
3.5-7% AA / 4-6.1% Beta

name: Brewer's Gold, UK
description:
Brewers Gold is a complex bittering hop that is noted to have a sharp or pungent bittering quality. It also imparts a fruity yet spicy aroma as well as having a black currant characteristic. It is on the low end of the bittering hop scale at 8 to 10% AAU typically. Brewers Gold can be used in a wide range of styles from English Ales to German Lagers and adds a decidely 'European' element to the beer. These make a good partner to noble varieties such as Tettnang and Hallertauer.

Used for: English Ale, German LagersSubstitutions: Bullion, Chinook, Galena

name: German Tradition
description:
Close descendant of Hallertauer Mittelfrueh bred for high yield.
Used for: Lager, Pilsner, Bock, some WeizensAroma: Medium intense floral and herbal (grassy) tones
Substitutes: Hallertau Mittelfruh, Liberty, HersbruckerStorage: Unknown
5-7% AA / 4-5% Beta

name: Summer (Summer Saaz)
description:
Apricot and melon characters are more apparent when dry hopping.
Used for: AlesAroma: Subtle, light apricot and melon flavors
Substitiutions: UnknownStorage: Unknown
4-7.5% AA / 4.8-6.7% Beta

name: Calypso
description:
A new, dual-purpose hop from the Hopsteiner breeding program that may establish itself as "special".
Used for: Ales, Stouts and Barley WinesAroma: Not as tropical as the name might imply but rich in both stone fruits (pear and peaches, notes of cherry) and citrus.
Substitutions: UnknownStorage: Good (65-70% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
12-14% AA / 5-6% Beta

name: Lemondrop
description:
Notes: Good for citrusy IPA, APA, IPL, or Saisons. Should be used with a hop with more distinct flavor that would benefit from the lemon flavor.

Aroma: Lemony, floral, earthy, herbal, grassy, pine, pepper

name: Pacifica
description:
Aroma hop developed from Hallertauer Mittelfrueh in New Zealand (1994).  Blend of old and new world taste including Orange marmalade and citrus aroma notes when used in late addition.  Soft finish if used in bittering.  
Substitutes: Chinook, Hallertauer Mittelfrueh

name: Taiheke
description:
Formerly called 'Cascade, New Zealand'.  Flowers, citrus and spice with grapefruit the noticeable fragrance quite often. This medium aroma balances the low bittering value. Very popular hop among craft brewers.

Used for: Pale Ales, IPAs, PortersSubstitutions: Centennial, Amarillo

name: Riwaka
description:
Formerly called B-Saaz, this was developed from old line Saazer hops in New Zealand.  
Used for: New world pale ale, regional pilsnersAroma: Strong, hoppy. Some grapefruit and citrus character.

name: Millenium
description:
Originally developed as part of the Haas breeding program in the US, Millenium entered production in 2000.  It is a very high alpha hops used for bittering.
Aroma: Mild, herbalSubstitutes: Columbus, Tomahawk, Zeus and Nugget

name: Neo1
description: Another neomexicanus breed and native of New Mexico.  A high percent of limonene and linalool gives this hop a distinctive strong lemon-citrus character.  Sister to Amallia.

name: Centennial Hop Extract
description:
CO2 Hop Extract -sold in both 0.5kg (150 gma), 1 kg (300 gma), 2 kg, 3kg and 4kg cans.  Extracted from Centennial hops and only for use in the boil.  Measure out liquid in ml for use.

Check alpha percentage listed here against the can as alpha may vary by season and manufacturer.

name: Boadicea
description:
Released in 2004. Excellent for finishing and dry hopping.
Used for: AlesAroma: Mild floral and spicy characteristics with slightly grassy overtones
Substitutions: UnknownStorage: Unknown
7-10% AA / 3-4% Beta

name: Magnum
description:
German Hallertauer hybrid, widely used in Germany
Used for: German ales and lagersAroma: Good aroma and stable spicy flavor
Substitutes: N/A

name: First Gold
description:
Dwarf hop with English Golding character
Used for: Ales, ESBAroma: Similar to other Golding varieties, spicy
Substitutes: East Kent Goldings, Crystal

name: Perle
description:
Used for: General purpose bittering for US and German ales, lagers
Aroma: Slightly spicy, pleasant aroma, mintySubstitutes: Chinook, Galena, Northern Brewer
Examples: Sierra Nevada Pale Ale, Pale Bock

name: Atlas
description:
A cross between Brewers Gold and Slovenian wild hops.  Primarily a bittering hop with pleasant bitterness and aroma.  
Used for: Bittering ales, lagersSubstitutes: Brewers Gold

name: Rakau (Alpharoma)
description:
Previously known as Alpharoma. Suited for new world styles where brash fruit character and big but well constructed bitterness is desired. Has been compared to Nelson Sauvin as a "flavor hop".
Used for: Pale Ale, IPA, LagerAroma: Tropical fruit, passion fruit, apricot/peach
Substitutions: Amarillo, SummitStorage: Good
10-11% AA / 4.6-6% Beta

name: Saphir
description:
A new noble breed as an alternative to Hallertau Mittelfrueh in an attempt to make it more disease resistant and commercially viable.  Similar in character to Hallertau varieties.  
Used for: Pilsners, lagers, Belgian whites.  
Substitutes: Hallertau Mittelfrueh

name: Strisslespalt
description:
Aroma hops used widely in the Alsace area of France.
Used for: Pilsner, lager, wheatAroma: Medium intensity, pleasant, hoppy
Substitutes: Mt Hood, Crystal, Hallertauer Hersbruck

name: Apollo
description:
Super high alpha variety from the Hopsteiner breeding program released in 2006.  High alpha and low cohumulone makes it a great bittering hop.  
Adds a strong grapefruit/hop note if added late in boil.Substitutes: Nugget, Columbus, Tomahawk, Zeus

name: Orion
description:
Cross between Perle and an experimental variety
Used for: Bittering and aromaAroma: Pleasant, hoppy
Substitutes: Perle

name: Wye Challenger
description:
Spicy, clean, citrus aroma with distinct herbal notes.

Used for: English Ales, English IPA, Red Ale, Bitter, Stout, PorterSubstitutions: N/A

name: Polaris
description:
Very high alpha and stunninly high oil content. Its aroma variously described as "ice candy", eucalyptus, peppermint, and citrus. A variety with bold taste and differentiating flavor.
Used for: Lagers, Ales, Pale Ales, IPAAroma: Intense floral and pleasant mint tones
Substitutes: UnknownStorage: Unknown
19-23% AA / 5-7% Beta

name: Southern Aroma 2018
description: Southern Aroma is a South African bred aroma, daylight neutral hop whose pedigree is a diploid seedling originating from Saaz and Hallertauer Mettelfreuh crossing.  The aroma profile includes floral, fields of flowers, woody/spicy, and fruity.  Total oil content is around 0.6 to 0.8 percent, alpha acids range from 3 to 6 percent, and cohumulone is very low at about 16 to 22 percent.  A hop with classic noble hop character and a fruity South African terroir backdrop.  Works well with classic European and English styles where traditional noble hops may be used, but also hop forward beers of American and Belgian origins.  Possible similar hops: Motueka.

name: Southern Aroma 2017
description: Southern Aroma is a South African bred aroma, daylight neutral hop whose pedigree is a diploid seedling originating from Saaz and Hallertauer Mettelfreuh crossing.  The aroma profile includes floral, fields of flowers, woody/spicy, and fruity.  Total oil content is around 0.6 to 0.8 percent, alpha acids range from 3 to 6 percent, and cohumulone is very low at about 16 to 22 percent.  A hop with classic noble hop character and a fruity South African terroir backdrop.  Works well with classic European and English styles where traditional noble hops may be used, but also hop forward beers of American and Belgian origins.  Possible similar hops: Motueka.

name: Southern Aroma 2016
description: TBD

name: Dr. Rudi
description:
A dual purpose / bittering hop with classic resinous pine and lifted citrus characters.

Used for: AlesSubstitutions: N/A

name: Vojvodina
description: A cross between Northern Brewer and a Golding male.  Mild, woody aroma with hints of tobacco and woody aroma.  Some noble character but more rounded.  Somewhat scarce availability.

name: Summit Hop Extract
description:
CO2 Hop Extract -sold in both 0.5kg (150 gma), 1 kg (300 gma), 2 kg, 3kg and 4kg cans.  Extracted from Summit hops and only for use in the boil.  Measure out liquid in ml for use.

Check alpha percentage listed here against the can as alpha may vary by season and manufacturer.

name: East Kent Goldings (EKG)
description:
Also known as Canterbury Hops by some, although others will dispute this fact. East Kent Goldings gracefully defines the English Pale Ales and Ales produced by the region, it is quintessentially English.
Used for: English Ale, Porter, Scottish and Irish Ale, Stout, Strong Ale, ESB, Saison, Barleywine.Aroma: Floral, aromatic, earthy, slightly sweet spicy flavor
Substitutes: First Gold, Fuggles, other Golding varieties, Progress, Target, and Whitbread GoldingStorage: Good/Fair 965-80% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
4-7% AA / 1.9-2.8% Beta

name: Bravo
description:
A second generation super high alpha hops from the Hopsteiner breeding program released in 2006.  Good bittering hop.
Aroma: Fruity and floral aroma.Substitutes: Columbus, Zeus, Tomahawk

name: Tettnang
description:
Used for: German ales, lagers and wheat beer
Aroma: Noble, mild, fine, slightly spicySubstitutes: Saaz, Spalt
Examples: Sam Adams Octoberfest, Anderson Valley ESB

name: J17/63 (African Queen) 2016
description:
Gooseberries, Cassis, Chilli, Gazpacho.

Experimental SAB hop. J17/63 is a day neutral high alpha variety, which requires moderate planting distances and an average of 9-10000 strings and 27-30000 bines per hectare.  Bines are vigorous and perform well on a standard framework. The medium sized cones with an average volume of 0.24g are semi tight, dense and pick very easily.  The cone to leaf ratio is 60:40.  Alpha development is normal.Because of the excellent alpha acids content and good yields, J17/63 gives a very high alpha acid production per hectare.

Cohumulone 26.5%, Storeability (Pellets) TBC, Isomerisation (Pellets) TBC, Total Oil ml/100g 1.3%, Humulene 21.4%, Caryophyllene 12.8%, Hum/Car Ratio 1.7, Farnesene 4.9, Myrcene 28.4%

name: Sladek
description:
Hybrid variety of Saaz origin with noble hoppy taste and aroma.  Generally recommended for middle-hopping about 20 min before end of boil.  Not a replacement for Saaz, but complimentary in Lagers.  
Used for: LagerSubstitutes: Saaz

name: Celeia
description:
A dual purpose hops that is a hybrid between Savinjski Golding, Aurora and Slovenian wild hops.  Similar in aroma to Saaz.  
Used for: Light lagers, Pilsners, Belgian ales.Substitutes: Saaz, Styrian Goldings

name: Opal
description:
New variety from the hop research center in Hull.
Used for: Aroma hops in continental stylesAroma: High aroma hops with hints of spice and subtle citrus.
Substitutes: Unknown

name: Kazbek
description: From the Czech Republic, released in 2008. The classic noble spice of saaz, but with a earthy lemon peel tone.  Primarily an aroma hop for whirlpool or dry hopping.  Noble hop character but high oil content.  Similar to a very strong Saaz with notes of citrus and grapefruit.  Substitute: Saaz

name: Admiral
description:
Bittering hops derived from Wye Challenger.  Good high-alpha bittering hops.
Used for: AlesAroma: Primarily for bittering
Substitutes: Target, Northdown, Challenger

name: Citra Hop Extract
description:
CO2 Hop Extract -sold in both 0.5kg (150 gma), 1 kg (300 gma), 2 kg, 3kg and 4kg cans.  Extracted from Citra hops and only for use in the boil.  Measure out liquid in ml for use.

Check alpha percentage listed here against the can as alpha may vary by season and manufacturer.

name: Cryo - Eukanot
description: An aromatic hop with some tropical, citrus, fruity, and herbal notes.  Lupulin powder - typically used during the whirlpool/steep or dry hop phases at about half the volume of pellet hops to mazimize aroma/flavor.  Concentrated to enhance hop oils.  Store near freezing.

name: Horizon
description:
Good dual purpose hops derived from Nugget hops in Oregon (1970)
Used for: All purpose Ales, LagersAroma: Pleasant, hoppy
Substitutes: Magnum or other high alpha hops

name: Fuggle
description:
Traditional English-type aroma hop.
Used for: English Ales, ESB, Bitter, LagersAroma: Mild, soft, fruity, spicy, woody
Substitute: Fuggle (U.S.), Willamette, Styrian GoldingStorage: Good/Very Good (70-80% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
3-5.6% AA 2-3% Beta

name: Fuggles
description:
Used for: General purpose bittering/aroma for English Ales, Dark Lagers
Aroma: Mild, soft, grassy, floral aromaSubstitute: East Kent Goldings, Williamette
Examples: Samuel Smith's Pale Ale, Old Peculiar, Thomas Hardy's Ale

name: US4/78 2010
description: US4/78 is cultivated on the Outiniqua pass in the George region and was developed from Saaz and Hallertauer parents.

name: Hallertau
description:
This traditional German land-race variety has limited acreage in the U.S. 
Used for: lager, pilsner, bock, wheat, Munich Helles, or Belgian style.Aroma: considered mild, pleasant, and slightly flowery and spicy.
Substitutions: Liberty, German Hallertau, German TraditionStorage: Fair (50-60% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
3.5-5.5% AA / 3.5-5.5% Beta

Experimental SAB hop. J17/63 is a day neutral high alpha variety, which requires moderate planting distances and an average of 9-10000 strings and 27-30000 bines per hectare.  Bines are vigorous and perform well on a standard framework. The medium sized cones with an average volume of 0.24g are semi tight, dense and pick very easily.  The cone to leaf ratio is 60:40.  Alpha development is normal.Because of the excellent alpha acids content and good yields, J17/63 gives a very high alpha acid production per hectare.

name: J17/63 2014
description:
Gooseberries, Cassis, Chilli, Gazpacho.

Experimental SAB hop. J17/63 is a day neutral high alpha variety, which requires moderate planting distances and an average of 9-10000 strings and 27-30000 bines per hectare.  Bines are vigorous and perform well on a standard framework. The medium sized cones with an average volume of 0.24g are semi tight, dense and pick very easily.  The cone to leaf ratio is 60:40.  Alpha development is normal.Because of the excellent alpha acids content and good yields, J17/63 gives a very high alpha acid production per hectare.

Cohumulone 26.5%, Storeability (Pellets) TBC, Isomerisation (Pellets) TBC, Total Oil ml/100g 1.3%, Humulene 21.4%, Caryophyllene 12.8%, Hum/Car Ratio 1.7, Farnesene 4.9, Myrcene 28.4%

name: CTZ Hop Hash
description:
Technically this is lupulin powder similar to Cryo-hops.  It is intended for use primarily in the whirlpool, hot steep or for dry hopping.

Columbus, Tomahawk and Zeus are collectively called CTZ and are similar in character and often blended.  They provide citrus aromas, black peper, licorace and curry notes.

name: Spalt Spalter
description:
Available only from the Spalt region. fire aroma is unique despite genetic sililarities to Saaz, Tettnanger.
Used for: Traditional German beers, Altbiers, LagersAroma: Fine/spicy, delicate, herbal, woody, floral
Substitutes: Saaz, TettnangerStorage: Poor
2.5-3.5 AA / 3-5% Beta

name: Hersbrucker
description:
Hersbrucker Hops is similar to the noble hop varieties with its low co-humulone level.
Aroma: Classicly spicy, herbal, with hints of citrus and stone fruit.Used for: German and Bavarian style Lagers, Pilsners, Hefeweizens, Dunkles, and Bocks
Substitutions: Mt. Hood, Strisselspalt, Hallertau Mittelfruh, LibertyStorage: Fair (55%-65% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
2-5% AA / 4-6% Beta

name: Meridian
description: Grown primarily in Willamette Valley - a unique variety with crisp flavors of lemon, mixed berry and tropical fruit.  Complements many other hop flavors very well.  Some notes of nectarine, apricots, with some pine. Use in: Belgians, IPAs, Blondes.  Substitute: Citra, Glacier, Centennial

name: Idaho #7
description:
Notes: Dual purpose, high alpha acid

Aroma: Tropical fruit, orange, apricot, pine.

name: Lublin (Lubelski)
description:
Lublin, also called "Lubelski", was bred from Saaz and carries with it many of the same characteristics.
Used for: Bohemian lagers and PilsnersAroma: Noble, mild flavor similar to Saaz
Substitutes: Saaz, Tettnanger, SterlingStorage: Good (70%-75% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
3-5% AA / 2.5-4% Beta

name: Hallertau Magnum
description:
German Hallertauer hybrid, widely used in Germany. Extremely appropriate for early boil additions.
Used for: German ales and lagers, bitters, IPAs, pilsners, pale ales, stouts.Aroma: somewhat unnoticeable aroma; stable spicy flavor
Substitutes: Hallertau Taurus, Columbus, NuggetStorage: Excellent (80%-85% AA after 6 months at 20 C)
12-14% AA / 4.5-5.5% Beta

name: Multihead
description: MultiHead is a neomexicanus breed native to New Mexico and is so named because of its tendency to produce dual cones. It is a unique hop in the industry and in brewing features a heady, floral aroma and some citrus elements.

name: Cryo - Loral
description: Loral is a floral, citrus, fruity, herbal hops used for its aromatic qualities.  Versatile.  Lupulin powder - typically used during the whirlpool/steep or dry hop phases at about half the volume of pellet hops to mazimize aroma/flavor.  Concentrated to enhance hop oils. Store near freezing.

name: Loral
description: Released in 2016, Loral HBC 291 has a noble heritage and crosses old world and new world aromatics.  Pleasant aroma including floral, pepper, lemon citrus and dark fruit notes.  Suitable for many beer styles.

name: Vic Secret
description:
The clean, distinct fruit and pine characters of Vic Secret are best accessed by dry hopping or whirlpool additions. Late kettle additions have been found to impart a pleasant earthy character, but little fruit. Maintains very high levels of alpha acid so brewers may find it easier to craft the right balance in their beer by dry hopping. First commercial harvest in 2013.
Uses: Ales, Lagers, Experimental AlesAroma: Clean, distinct fruit and pine
Substitutions: UnknownStorage: Unknown
14-17% AA / 2.2-2.8% Beta

name: Vanguard
description:
Diploid seedling made in 1982, released in 1997. Hallertau Mitterfrueh parentage.
Used for: European lagers, alesAroma: Strong aromatic notes
Substitutes: Hallertauer Mittelfrueh

name: Equinox (HBC 366)
description:
A pronounced aroma profile with citrus, tropical fruit, floral and herbal characteristics. Specific descriptors include lemon, lime, papaya, apple, and green pepper.

Used for: Experimental AleAroma: Exceptional aroma profile includes notes of citrus, tropical and pine 
Substitutions: UnknownStorage: Unknown
14.4-15.6% AA / 4.6-5.1% Beta

name: Sorachi Ace
description:
Developed by Sapporo Breweries and used in their beers - has a Brewer's gold and Saaz heritage.  Reported to be lemony in flavor and aroma.  
Used for: Saison, IPA or other beer where lemon/citrus is desirable.Substitutes: Admiral, Cascade

name: Ariana
description: Developed at the hop research center in Hull, Germany.  A cross between Hurkules and a wild male.  Aromas include black currant, grapefruit, gooseberry, geranium and vanilla.

name: African Queen
description: A high alpha hop from South Africa with interesting bittering potential and fruity flavors.  Fruity aroma includes hints of blueberry, cassis, passion fruit, citrus, stone fruit, black currant, tea, lemongrass and even chili.  Can be used both for bittering and as a late addition.

name: Styrian Goldings
description:
A seedless version of Fuggles grown in Slovenia
Used for: Bittering, finishing for a wide variety of European Beers. Popular in Europe and the United KingdomAroma: Mild, soft, grassy, floral aroma. Similar to Fuggles.
Substitutes: Fuggles, Williamette
